Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Elucidating Evolutionary Histories of Multiple Chipmunk Parasites Using Next Generation Sequencing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates the response of parasites to the diversification of their chipmunk hosts across temporally and spatially variable environments in western North America. Chipmunks are frequently infected with externally-parasitic sucking lice and internally-parasitic pinworms. It is unclear if parasite lineages are restricted to individual chipmunk species and diversifying in tandem with the host lineages (codiversification), or if they are adapted to a resource shared among chipmunks and thus can infect any species of chipmunk they encounter. This project tests for codiversification among each parasite and the hosts and investigates the role of climate in determining parasite distribution and diversity. The research uses a combination of geographic mapping and genetic sequencing techniques to determine the influence of climate, geography, and species associations in evolutionary diversification.

An integrated view of the evolutionary history of hosts and parasites has wide-ranging implications, including consequences of climate change on pathogens and parasites. Beyond the current interest in biotic responses to climate change, studying host-parasite associations allows for testing of foundational coevolutionary rules and hypotheses. This research will provide training for undergraduate and graduate students in field, museum, and molecular lab research. Additionally, this project will feed into an effort to integrate museum specimens and databases into undergraduate courses through inquiry-driven student projects that raise awareness of the value of natural history collections. Through this research, students will be introduced to cutting-edge analytical and collaborative approaches in bioinformatics. Chipmunks are familiar, highly visible, and provide a gateway to conversations with school groups, the public, and others about conservation, evolution, and parasites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mammals are frequently infected with parasites, but we know relatively little about the dynamics or consequences of these long-term associations. This research investigates the response of parasites to the diversification of their chipmunk hosts across variable environments in western North America. Chipmunks are frequently infected with external parasites, such as sucking lice, and internal parasites, such as pinworms. We are using DNA sequence data to determine if parasite lineages are restricted to individual chipmunk species and diversifying in tandem with the host lineages (codiversification), or if they are adapted to resources shared among chipmunks, and thus can infect any species of chipmunk they encounter. This project also investigates the role of changing environments in determining parasite distribution and diversity. The research uses a combination of geographic mapping (GIS) and genetic sequencing techniques to determine the influence of climate, geography, and species associations in evolutionary diversification.

The results of this research indicate that while parasite lineages appear to be restricted to host species, or very closely related host species, their evolutionary history suggests that not all parasites have codiversified with the host species. Pinworm lineages appear to be able to switch to infecting new host species, although it is relatively rare, suggesting that variation among host populations or host species interactions are limiting the ability to switch to new hosts. Preliminary analysis of lice genetic relationships suggests that evolutionary lineages are restricted to individual host species, but on-going, in-depth analyses are required to determine their evolutionary history and the responses between host and parasite. We have not identified climatic factors that may restrict parasite distributions or impact their ability to infect new hosts, however, climate may indirectly affect interactions of the parasites by impacting host distributions.

            This research is a product of collaborations across multiple institutions (University of New Mexico, University of Illinois, Denver Museum of Nature & Science) and scientists at all career stages, from undergraduate students to established faculty. Additionally, middle school students have participated in the process by learning about parasites and by collecting lice from museum specimens and properly recording data. Undergraduate students have collected specimens and participated in the generation and analysis of DNA sequence data and co-authored publications. This project has been used to introduce middle and high school students to topics in evolution and the tools used to study and integrate across many aspects of biology.
